# Copilot Instructions for vibe-mofa

## Project Overview

This is the Vibing Framework for MoFA (vibe-mofa). This repository contains the core framework and tools for the MoFA project.

## Code Style and Conventions

### General Guidelines
- Write clear, readable, and maintainable code
- Follow industry best practices for the languages used in this project
- Use meaningful variable and function names
- Keep functions small and focused on a single responsibility
- Add comments only when necessary to explain complex logic

### Formatting
- Use consistent indentation (spaces preferred over tabs)
- Keep lines to a reasonable length (typically 80-120 characters)
- Use blank lines to separate logical sections of code

## Architecture and Design Patterns

### Project Structure
- Follow the existing directory structure when adding new files
- Group related functionality together
- Keep configuration files at the root level when appropriate

### Code Organization
- Separate concerns appropriately
- Use modular design principles
- Avoid tight coupling between components

## Documentation

### Code Documentation
- Document public APIs and interfaces
- Include usage examples for complex functionality
- Keep documentation up-to-date with code changes

### README and Project Documentation
- Update README.md when adding significant features
- Document setup and installation procedures
- Include contribution guidelines when applicable

## Testing

### Test Requirements
- Write tests for new functionality when test infrastructure exists
- Follow existing test patterns and conventions
- Ensure tests are clear and maintainable

### Test Coverage
- Aim for comprehensive coverage of critical paths
- Include edge cases and error handling in tests

## Git and Version Control

### Commit Messages
- Write clear, descriptive commit messages
- Use present tense ("Add feature" not "Added feature")
- Keep the first line concise (50 characters or less)
- Add detailed description in the body when necessary

### Branches
- Use descriptive branch names
- Follow any existing branch naming conventions

## Dependencies

### Adding Dependencies
- Only add dependencies when necessary
- Prefer well-maintained, popular libraries
- Document the purpose of new dependencies
- Keep dependencies up-to-date

### Security
- Avoid adding dependencies with known vulnerabilities
- Review security implications of new code
- Don't commit secrets or sensitive information

## Best Practices

### Performance
- Consider performance implications of new code
- Avoid premature optimization
- Profile before optimizing

### Error Handling
- Handle errors gracefully
- Provide meaningful error messages
- Don't suppress errors silently

### Code Reviews
- Make small, focused changes
- Ensure code is tested before review
- Be responsive to feedback

## Project-Specific Guidelines

### Framework Philosophy
- Keep the framework flexible and extensible
- Maintain backward compatibility when possible
- Document breaking changes clearly

### Contributors
- Welcome contributions from the community
- Follow the existing code style
- Ensure changes align with project goals
